title: 13 - Fair Value Gap - Imbalance and Inefficiency Trading

fair_value_gap.llm_summary: Fair Value Gap (FVG) is a 3-candle price imbalance where middle candle's wick does NOT overlap with candles on either side, creating a 'gap' or inefficiency. This represents an area where price moved so fast that normal buying/selling didn't occur - an imbalance. FVG appears when strong momentum causes price to skip levels. Smart Money typically returns to fill these gaps (rebalance). FVGs act as support/resistance and optimal entry zones. Bullish FVG = gap below current price (support). Bearish FVG = gap above current price (resistance).
key_rules: FVG = 3-candle pattern with middle candle wick not overlapping
Represents price imbalance/inefficiency
Market tends to return to fill FVGs (rebalance)
Bullish FVG = support zone, Bearish FVG = resistance zone
Acts as optimal entry point when filled

bullish_fvg.llm_summary: Bullish FVG (also called Demand Imbalance) forms during strong upward move when price gaps up leaving inefficiency below. Pattern: 3 candles where middle bullish candle's low wick doesn't touch first candle's high or third candle's low. The gap between first candle high and third candle low is the Bullish FVG zone. Acts as SUPPORT - when price returns to fill this gap during pullback, it's optimal long entry. Smart Money often places buy orders in Bullish FVG zones.
key_rules: Forms during strong bullish moves
Gap below current price = support zone
Optimal long entry when price returns to fill
Buy within the FVG zone during pullbacks

bearish_fvg.llm_summary: Bearish FVG (also called Supply Imbalance) forms during strong downward move when price gaps down leaving inefficiency above. Pattern: 3 candles where middle bearish candle's high wick doesn't touch first candle's low or third candle's high. The gap between first candle low and third candle high is the Bearish FVG zone. Acts as RESISTANCE - when price returns to fill this gap during retracement, it's optimal short entry. Smart Money often places sell orders in Bearish FVG zones.
key_rules: Forms during strong bearish moves
Gap above current price = resistance zone
Optimal short entry when price returns to fill
Sell within the FVG zone during retracements

fvg_fill_rebalance.llm_summary: FVG Fill (or Rebalance) occurs when price returns to the Fair Value Gap zone to fill the inefficiency. Market has natural tendency to rebalance - 70-80% of FVGs get filled eventually. Full fill = price completely fills the gap. Partial fill = price enters FVG but doesn't fill completely. Unfilled FVG remains as strong support/resistance. When FVG fills, it often provides excellent entry with tight stop loss above/below the FVG. The fill represents Smart Money re-entering or institutional order absorption.
key_rules: 70-80% of FVGs get filled eventually
Full fill = complete gap closure
Partial fill = price enters but doesn't complete
FVG fill = optimal entry point
Place stops beyond the FVG zone

fvg_trading_strategy.llm_summary: FVG Trading Strategy: 1) Identify trend direction, 2) Spot FVG formation during impulse moves, 3) Wait for price to retrace/pull back, 4) Enter when price reaches FVG zone, 5) Place stop beyond FVG, 6) Target next structure level. Bullish trend: buy when price fills Bullish FVG. Bearish trend: sell when price fills Bearish FVG. Combine with other confluences (inducement, order blocks, premium/discount). FVG entries provide excellent risk/reward ratios.
strategy_steps: 7. Target next swing or structure level

imbalance_inefficiency.llm_summary: Imbalance and Inefficiency are the core concepts underlying FVG. Imbalance = unequal buy/sell pressure causing rapid price movement. Inefficiency = price levels that were skipped due to imbalance, creating 'unfair' pricing where normal market participants didn't get to transact. Market seeks efficiency - tends to return to these zones to allow proper price discovery. FVG, Order Blocks, and Breaker Blocks all represent various forms of imbalance/inefficiency that market aims to rebalance.
key_rules: Imbalance = unequal buy/sell pressure
Inefficiency = skipped price levels
Market seeks to rebalance inefficiencies
FVG is visual representation of inefficiency

key_insights: FVG = 3-candle imbalance where middle candle wick doesn't overlap adjacent candles
70-80% of FVGs get filled (market seeks rebalance)
Bullish FVG = support zone, Bearish FVG = resistance zone
FVG fill provides optimal entry with tight stops
Forms during strong impulse moves (high momentum)
Represents price inefficiency that market returns to correct
Combine FVG with trend, inducement, and premium/discount for high probability setups
